title: Declining a Second Piece of Birthday Cake

content.text: At a Dutch birthday party, it's common to be offered cake. It is perfectly polite to say no, especially if you give a nice compliment!

data.tip: The 'ee' sounds like the 'ay' in 'hay'. The 'lijk' at the end sounds like 'luk'.

content.title: Refuse Politely
content.setting: You are at a colleague's birthday party. The host offers you a second piece of cake.

content.text: To say you are full, the Dutch use the expression 'Ik zit vol', which literally means 'I sit full'. It's a very common phrase after a meal.

data.tip: This 'o' sound is short and sharp, like the 'o' in 'pot'.

content.title: Give a Reason
content.setting: The host is very hospitable and wants to make sure you don't want more cake.

conversation_flow.title: State that you are full.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Dank je! Weet je het zeker? Een klein stukje?

content.text: To ask for something politely, you can start your question with 'Mag ik...?', which means 'May I...?'.

data.tip: The 'a' is a short, open sound, like in the English word 'path'.

content.text: A very important Dutch word is 'gezellig'. It means cozy, fun, or a nice atmosphere. Complimenting a party by calling it 'gezellig' is always a good idea!

data.tip: The 'g' at the beginning is a soft, throaty sound, typical in Dutch.

content.title: Ask for Something Else
content.setting: The host understands you are full. Now you can ask for a drink and give a final compliment.

conversation_flow.title: Ask if you can have a glass of water, please.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ah, oké. Dat snap ik. Wil je misschien iets anders drinken?

conversation_flow.title: Compliment the host on the nice party.
End the conversation.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Dank je wel! Fijn dat je er bent.
